video.description:
The sun rises and it sets. Through liquid time, we will follow a rabbit past different homes, different lives until we find our own. The Airbnb traveling experience is very unique and very personal. We look for a place that, for that short period of time, will become our home. Signs of people that have been here are embedded all around us and as we pass through them, we leave our own. When we started concepting ideas for the project we felt a strong desire, almost a need to show this flowing cycle. We move past apartments where we see lives, apartments where time passes just a little too quickly, apartments where we want to stay a little longer. As we watch the warm morning in Barcelona become a cool night in New Zealand a particular feeling evokes inside us; a feeling of a dream.

BRAND
Airbnb

CONCEPT DEVELOPMENT
Bipolar Studio

DIRECTION, PRODUCTION, CGI
Bipolar Studio

video.description:
Coming soon in VR!

www.bipolarstudio.la

CASE STUDY VIDEO: https://vimeo.com/260363413

Pilots in two different vehicles converge at high speeds, aligning with each other for a brief encounter.
We wanted to create a cinematic with the Porsche 911 Turbo S, that felt more like a short, or a segment from a film rather than a traditional commercial.

It was important for us to capture the dual nature of the vehicle; the minimal, almost sculptural beauty with the brutal force that propels it into motion. Through art direction, cinematography, and animation we brought this feeling out, a feeling that in one word we defined as: brutality.

BRAND
Porsche

CONCEPT
Bipolar Studio

DIRECTION, PRODUCTION & CGI
Bipolar Studio

video.description:
Explore British Columbia’s Great Bear rainforest in an interactive virtual journey, flying over the lakes and hiking through forests.  

The film for the first time ever granted people from anywhere in the world the ability to submerge themselves in the raw beauty and epic vistas of British Columbia’s most remote locations. It was launched as an installation at select airports across North America in 2015.

“A mind-blowing journey to breathtaking British Columbia, Canada, without ever leaving where I live in New York City.” -The Huffington Post.
